DEVICES_PAGE_WORKFLOW_HTML: <li>Create a device with unique name and a password. You will be provided with a shell command you can then
copy-paste into the terminal of your device.
<li>Enter the same password you used to create the device and the device will appear in the list below after
connecting to this server. All further interaction with the device will be done through this encrypted SSH channel.
<li>Press "SIGN IN" button to sign in into your device. You don't need to use root's credentials if you are
not going to perform superuser-only operations
<li>When signed in you can then open an in-browser terminal session to this device under the credentials you used
or create a private HTTP proxy for any port on your device
DEVICES_PAGE_SECURITY_HTML: <li>Credentials you use to sign in into your device are readable to this server. Although these credentials are never
stored to disk and only live in the server's memory while the session exists, a compromised server might have a
different idea what to do with your information.
<li>A more secure apporoach would be to set up your own server (preferably after inspecting the source code) so you
trust the credentials only to a reliable server.
<li>Some web services protect their users from phishing sites, for which they detect and prevent proxies and <iframe>
tags from working. You will have to configure an exception for the server in such case. For Webmin, you can achieve

this by adding to the end of /etc/webmin/config: 
referers={origin}
PROXY_TPL_404: Try to reopen this page from the Device List
PROXY_TPL_502: Looks like nobody is listening on this port
PROXY_AUTH_LABEL: Remote service needs HTTP BASIC AUTH
APP_AUTH_SELF_REGISTRATION_MESSAGE: If you are a new user, you can invent any unused login and the password to sign in
ERROR_INVALID_PASSWORD: Password length must be at least 6 characters
